sys_hub_action_type_definition.description: Extract summary and readability information from JSON returns by AI Skill
sys_hub_action_type_definition.name: Extract Summary Information

sys_variable_value.value: {"name":"root","children":[{"name":"Summary","children":[],"type":"string","jpath":"$.Summary","previewValue":"This article explains the Windows key, a standard keyboard key found on computers designed for Windows operating systems. The key is identified by the Windows logo and is typically located between the Ctrl and Alt keys on the left side of the keyboard, with a possible duplicate on the right side. The article describes the key's primary function: pressing it alone toggles between the Start screen and current application in Windows 8.x, or brings up the Start menu in Windows 7/Vista. It also mentions that the Windows key can be combined with other keys for various shortcuts that vary by Windows version, referencing Wikipedia for a complete list. For keyboards without a Windows key, users can press Ctrl-Esc to access the Start menu, and Mac users running Windows through Boot Camp can use the Command key as a substitute."},{"name":"readability_score","children":[],"type":"string","jpath":"$.readability_score","previewValue":"7"},{"name":"readability_explanation","children":[],"type":"string","jpath":"$.readability_explanation","previewValue":"The article is generally well-written and informative, with clear explanations and good use of code formatting for key names. However, it suffers from outdated information (Windows 8.x references), lacks visual aids, and could benefit from better organization with subheadings to improve scannability."},{"name":"improvement","children":[],"type":"string","jpath":"$.improvement","previewValue":"• Update the content to include current Windows versions (Windows 10, 11) and remove outdated references to Windows 8.x and Vista • Add subheadings to break up the content into logical sections such as 'Location and Appearance', 'Basic Functions', and 'Alternative Methods' • Include a brief table or formatted list of the most common Windows key shortcuts instead of just referencing an external Wikipedia link"}],"type":"object","jpath":"$","previewValue":""}

{"Summary":"This article explains the Windows key, a standard keyboard key found on computers designed for Windows operating systems. The key is identified by the Windows logo and is typically located between the Ctrl and Alt keys on the left side of the keyboard, with a possible duplicate on the right side. The article describes the key's primary function: pressing it alone toggles between the Start screen and current application in Windows 8.x, or brings up the Start menu in Windows 7/Vista. It also mentions that the Windows key can be combined with other keys for various shortcuts that vary by Windows version, referencing Wikipedia for a complete list. For keyboards without a Windows key, users can press Ctrl-Esc to access the Start menu, and Mac users running Windows through Boot Camp can use the Command key as a substitute.","readability_score":7,"readability_explanation":"The article is generally well-written and informative, with clear explanations and good use of code formatting for key names. However, it suffers from outdated information (Windows 8.x references), lacks visual aids, and could benefit from better organization with subheadings to improve scannability.","improvement":"• Update the content to include current Windows versions (Windows 10, 11) and remove outdated references to Windows 8.x and Vista • Add subheadings to break up the content into logical sections such as 'Location and Appearance', 'Basic Functions', and 'Alternative Methods' • Include a brief table or formatted list of the most common Windows key shortcuts instead of just referencing an external Wikipedia link"}

{"Summary":"This article explains the Windows key, a standard keyboard key found on computers designed for Windows operating systems.
